matched.expectedTitle: Reflected XSS via Blacklist Bypass in XSS25
matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS via Filter Bypass in Solution Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the exact same vulnerability: a reflected XSS attack on the /xss25 endpoint's solution parameter that bypasses a blacklist filter. The expected finding describes a blacklist that blocks 'script', event handlers like onload/onerror, 'svg', and single quotes. The actual finding confirms these same blocked keywords and demonstrates successful bypass using alternative event handlers (onfocus, ontoggle, onstart, onpageshow). The actual finding provides extensive POC evidence with 4 successful test cases showing payloads like '<input onfocus=alert(1) autofocus>', '<details open ontoggle=alert(2)>', and '<select onfocus=alert(4) autofocus>' being reflected without encoding. Both describe the same attack vector, impact (session hijacking, cookie theft, phishing), and root cause (incomplete blacklist-based filtering instead of proper output encoding).

extra.title: Missing Security Headers Enable Multiple Attack Vectors
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding representing newly discovered infrastructure vulnerabilities. The finding identifies missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, X-Content-Type-Options) and explicitly disabled X-XSS-Protection. While not part of the expected application-level vulnerabilities, these are valid security misconfigurations that increase the impact of XSS and enable additional attack vectors like clickjacking and MIME sniffing attacks.

extra.title: Use of End-of-Life Python 2.7.18 with No Security Updates
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate finding identifying infrastructure risk. Python 2.7.18 reached EOL on January 1, 2020, meaning 5+ years without security updates. This is a valid vulnerability that exposes the application to unpatched interpreter and standard library vulnerabilities. While not part of the expected application-specific findings, this represents a significant security debt and compliance risk (PCI-DSS, HIPAA requirements).

extra.title: Outdated Werkzeug 1.0.1 with Known Security Vulnerabilities
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate finding identifying known CVEs in the web server framework. Werkzeug 1.0.1 (from March 2020) contains CVE-2023-25577 (path traversal) and CVE-2023-23934 (cookie parsing cache poisoning), both rated HIGH severity. This represents a real security risk from vulnerable dependencies. The finding correctly identifies the outdated component and associated CVEs, making it a valid new discovery beyond the expected findings.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Token Validation on Solution Submission Form
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding representing a newly discovered vulnerability. The pentest identified that the solution submission form lacks CSRF protection, allowing cross-site request forgery attacks. The POC demonstrates successful form submission without CSRF tokens and acceptance of cross-origin requests. This is a valid vulnerability that could allow attackers to submit solutions on behalf of authenticated users, though it was not part of the expected findings list.

extra.title: Information Disclosure via Verbose Error Messages in Solution Validation
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate finding identifying information leakage through detailed error messages. The application exposes Python TypeError exceptions with technical details when processing certain payloads, revealing internal application behavior and template expression processing. While LOW severity, this follows CWE-209 and aids attacker reconnaissance. This is a valid new discovery that wasn't part of the expected findings.

extra.title: Production Use of Werkzeug Development Server
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate finding identifying deployment misconfiguration. The application is using Werkzeug's development server (confirmed by Server header), which is explicitly not suitable for production due to lack of security hardening, DoS protection, and performance optimization. This represents a valid infrastructure vulnerability exposing the application to DoS attacks and performance issues. Flask documentation explicitly warns against this practice.

extra.title: Server Version Information Disclosure in HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate finding identifying information disclosure through the Server header. The application consistently exposes 'Server: Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18' in all HTTP responses, providing precise version information that aids attacker reconnaissance. While LOW severity on its own, this follows CWE-200 and security best practices recommend suppressing version information. This is a valid defensive measure that was identified beyond the expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Rate Limiting Enables Brute Force and DoS Attacks
extra.assessment: This is a legitimate finding identifying absence of rate limiting controls. The POC demonstrates that the application accepts unlimited rapid requests without throttling, delays, or CAPTCHA challenges. This enables brute force attacks (if there's a valid solution to discover), application-layer DoS, and resource exhaustion. The finding follows CWE-307 and CWE-770, representing a valid security control gap that was not part of the expected findings.
